title-group.article-title: Photo-induced antimicrobial and decontaminating agents: recent progresses in polymer and textile applications

author-notes.corresp: Kyung Hwa Hong, Kongju National University, Gongju 314-701, Republic of Korea. Email: hkh713@kongju.ac.kr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In recent years, antimicrobial and decontaminating products and materials have drawn a lot of attention due to the outbreaks of infectious diseases in the public, as well as potential and unwanted exposure to certain hazardous chemicals in the living environment. Photo-chemistry has revealed that both inorganic photo-catalysts and organic photo-sensitizers could generate some reactive oxygen species (ROSs) on certain polymeric surfaces under light exposure and these ROS can provide antimicrobial and decontaminating functions. Thus, researchers have been trying to incorporate the photo-active agents into various polymeric substrates to prepare self-decontaminating materials for medical applications, protective clothing, etc. This paper will provide a review of the recent research progresses in the area of photo-induced functional materials, specifically antimicrobial functions and decontamination abilities of the materials.

body.p: Not only environmental contaminations caused by anthropogenic toxic chemicals, but also the spreading of infectious diseases have become the major concerns to human and environmental health. Many technologies have been developed to prevent pathogenic microbial contamination and detoxify hazardous chemicals, simultaneously. The most commonly developed materials with biocidal functions and self-decontamination properties are polymers containing silver nanoparticles,1 quaternary ammonium salts2,3 and halamine structures.4–8 To improve the durability and reusability of the functional properties of the new polymeric materials, slow releasing of biocides or rechargeable biocidal sites were employed to provide durable functions on the materials.

Recently, photo-induced antimicrobial effects of some photo-sensitizers and photo-catalysts have been reported due to their ability to generate biocidal reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as singlet oxygen and hydroxyl radicals, under light exposure.9 These photo-induced antimicrobial functions have particular advantages in terms of the strong efficacy and multi-functionality, as well as being more environmentally friendly. Several inorganic photo-catalysts, including SiO2, ZnO, NiO and RuO2 (semiconductors), are commonly known as the photo-active agents;10 among them titanium dioxide (TiO2) is the most widely utilized one because of its reasonable photo-activity under ultraviolet (UV) and visible light exposure.11–14 Besides, TiO2 has many advantages for use as a functional agent since it is basically non-toxic, insoluble and comparatively inexpensive. TiO2 usually has a broader forbidden band (Eg = 3.2 eV) and can be excited by violet light (λ = 387.5 nm). Organic photo-sensitizers, such as porphyrin and Rose Bengal, as singlet oxygen generators, have been used in several medical treatments (for example, treatment for skin cancer) and diagnosis (for example, the diagnosis of bladder cancer).15–18 Few studies have reported the use of organic photo-sensitizers as antimicrobial agents on polymer surfaces. This paper provides a literature review on progresses of using inorganic and organic photo-activated agents as antimicrobial agents, with particular focus on polymeric materials.

sec.title: Inorganic photo-induced antimicrobial agents
sec.p:
TiO2 has many useful photo-active properties, which have already been investigated.19 TiO2 can decompose organic toxic compounds into harmless materials, as well as provide antimicrobial efficacy under ultraviolet A (UVA) light irradiation.9 The extent of the photo-activity depends on a wide range of structural features of the TiO2, including morphology, crystallinity, surface area, combination with other metals, etc.9–14 The use of TiO2 as a biocide was first demonstrated by Matsunaga et al.20 and, subsequently, there have been a number of reports presenting the disinfecting ability of TiO2 against bacteria, viruses and other microorganisms over the last 20 years.21–23 TiO2 can kill both Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria under light exposure, although Gram-positive bacteria are less sensitive due to their ability to form spores.24,25 In recent years, researchers have examined the biocidal activities of thin films with TiO2 anchored on surfaces for more practical applications.26–28 The basic mechanism of photo-catalytic degradation of organic pollutants in an UVA/TiO2 system is by the production of ROS; the concept is depicted in Figure 1.29,30 It is already established that conduction band electrons (e–) and valence band holes (h+) are generated when TiO2 is irradiated with photo-energy greater than its band gap energy (Eg = 3.2 eV).14 The photo-induced e– could reduce organic molecules, such as dye compounds,31,32 or react with electron acceptors such as O2 adsorbed on the Ti(III)-surface, inducing it to superoxide radical anion (O2•-), its protonated form hydroperoxyl radical (HO2•) and, subsequently, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). Meanwhile, the photo-induced hole (h+) can oxidize the organic molecules to form R+, or react with OH– or H2O, and oxidize them into hydroxyl radicals (•OH). The •OH, h+, O2•- and HO2• are highly reactive intermediates that can oxidize a variety of organic pollutants.33 In addition, an attractive feature of TiO2 photo-catalytic disinfection is its potential to be activated by sunlight and even daylight.25 Metal doping has been known to improve the visible light absorbance of TiO2,34,35 and increase its photo-catalytic activity under UV irradiation.36–38 Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of band energy levels of TiO2 photo-catalysts for organic material oxidation in an aerated system.

Photo-induced decontaminating functions of TiO2 and ZnO nanoparticle-treated polymers and textiles were reported by several research groups.39–45 The photo-induced self-cleaning and antimicrobial functions of the inorganic photo-active agents on surfaces of regular polymer and textiles were amazingly attractive and may have a bright future in the preparation of different functional products for consumers and industry. The self-cleaning performance of surfaces was recently reviewed with applications of different nanotechnologies on textile and polymeric surfaces.46 However, when TiO2 is applied in a polymer matrix, the photo-activity of the TiO2 affects not only the organic toxic compounds and bacteria around the polymer products, but also the polymer matrix, which impairs the mechanical properties of the polymer products.47,48 Inorganic materials do not have inherent interactions with organic surfaces and need adhesives or surface modifications to be bound onto surfaces of polymers or fibers, which is a limiting factor that also stimulated investigation on organic photo-active agents.

sec.title: Organic photo-induced antimicrobial agents
sec.p:
The photo-induced cytotoxicity property of the organic photo-sensitizer has been used in medicine and surgery, and the treatment is called photo-dynamic therapy (PDT). Photo-dynamic inactivation (PDI) is a promising approach to treat bacterial infections.49,50 This is based on the administration of a photo-sensitizer chemical compound that could be excited by the light of a specific wavelength, as shown in Table 1.51 This excitation usually happens under visible or near-infrared light. In PDT, a photo-sensitizer is injected into the bloodstream, and then the agent is absorbed by cells all over the body, but stays in malformed cells, such as tumor tissue, longer than it does in normal cells.49–51 Most clinically used photo-sensitizers show some inherent selectivity for the diseased tissue, probably due to the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect.52 Approximately 24–72 hours after injection, when most of the agent has left normal cells but remains in malformed cells, the cells are exposed to light.53–55 At the moment, if a suitable photo-source for the photo-sensitizer was supplied to the malformed cell area, the photo-sensitizer in the cells absorbs the light and excites from a ground state to an excited singlet state. In this Norrish type I photo-chemical reaction, the excited photo-sensitizer interacts with a biomolecule to produce a free radical. On the other hand, in the Norrish type II reaction, the excited singlet state of the photo-sensitizer undergoes intersystem crossing (ISC) to form a longer-lived excited triplet state. A combination action of the excited triplet photo-sensitizer and molecular oxygen (3O2) results in the formation of singlet oxygen (1O2), which is thought to be a main mediator of cellular death induced by PDT.56–58 Therefore, the two oxidative mechanisms are considered to be principally implicated in the photo-damage of malformed cells.59–61 The photo-activation reaction of porphyrin is schematized in Figure 2.62 Figure 2.
The photo-chemical reactions responsible for the generation of free radicals by porphyrins in a biological system.
Table 1.
Types of photosensitizing drugs
Class Approved drugs for photodynamic therapy Typical maximum absorption (nm) Typical absorption coefficienta
Porphyrins Porfimer sodium 630 10,000
Protoporphyrin IX (e.g. for methyl aminolevulinate and aminolevulinic acid) 633 10,000
Chlorins Verteporfin (benzoporphyrin derivative) 690 35,000
Temoporfin(meta-tetrahydroxyphenylchlorin) 652 30,000
Bacteriochlorins None yet approved 740 32,000
Phthalocyanines Sulfonated aluminum phthalocyanine mixture (approved in Russia) 680 110,000
Phenothiazinium compounds None yet approved 670 60,000
Texafrins None yet approved 734 42,000
a
Absorption of light cm−1, mol−1, l−1.

Photo-sensitizers can interact with bacterial cells, and the photo-sensitizers incorporating bacterial cells can be photo-inactivated when exposed to a proper light source.51–55 In general, Gram-positive bacteria can be easily interacted by photo-sensitizers, and therefore they can be readily photo-inactivated by most photo-sensitizers under UV exposure.63,64 However, Gram-negative bacteria are relatively impermeable to neutral or anionic chemicals since their electronegative charges cell walls, which is the reason that photo-sensitizers are not effective alone against Gram-negative bacteria.63,64 However, the addition of some cationic chemicals can improve the antibacterial efficacy of the process.50 Thus, the organic photo-sensitizers have powerful photo-induced activity and are used in the medical area.58–65

Benzophenone (BP), an aromatic ketone (diphenyl ketone), is an important compound in organic photo-chemistry and perfumery, as well as in organic synthesis. It has been used as a constituent of synthetic perfumes and as a precursor compound for making dyes, pesticides and drugs.66,67 So far, there has been no report about the significant toxicity of BP for human beings. BP was incorporated into polymeric materials by the following two methods: (1) chemical modification of polystyrene by incorporating BP structures; (2) cotton cellulose grafted with 4-hydroxybenzophenone by using 1,2,3,4,-butanetetra carboxylic acid (BTCA) as a cross-linker.68–72 Recent research showed that BP can be used as a photo-induced antibacterial agent on polymeric materials. The activated BP group on the polymers showed excellent antibacterial activities, as well as the ability of decomposing certain chemicals.68–72

Similar to BP and BP derivatives, anthraquinone and its derivatives could have similar structures and potential photo-active properties under light exposure according to the same photo-chemistry. Indeed, recent research results have proven that some anthraquinone derivatives possess similar photo-induced antibacterial and detoxifying functions on polymeric materials.73,74

sec.title: Photo-induced antibacterial ability of organic photo-active agents
sec.p:
Tables 2 and 3 show the photo-induced antibacterial results of the poly (styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) and the BP-linked cotton fabrics against S. aureus and E. coli, respectively.66,68 The numbers of colonies of S. aureus and E. coli were significantly reduced in both of the BP incorporated polymer materials, poly (styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) and BP grafted cotton fabrics when they were exposed to UVA (365 nm) or daylight for a short time. The antibacterial functions from the BP structures are due to radicals produced under light irradiation, such as white fluorescent lamps, as well as UVA (365 nm) lamps (see Table 2). Generally, radicals have a short life and tend to undergo fast reactions, since they are highly reactive chemical species possessing at least one unpaired electron.75 However, the BP incorporated polymer materials showed a long lifetime of radical activity, as shown in Figure 3.76 The results suggest that BP chromophoric groups, known to undergo n → π* transition by photo-exposure, turned to the triplet exited state through the ISC, and formed biradicals, as shown in Figure 4(b).77 Meanwhile, some of the triplet biradicals rapidly changed to hydroxyketyl radicals by abstracting hydrogen atoms78,79 from hydrogen donors, such as weak N–H or C–H bonds on polymers (Figure 4(c)), which induce longer life time of the radical activity.80 Therefore, it seems that the BP incorporated polymer materials could inhibit the growth of the bacteria by the photo-induced BP radicals, which might attack the bacteria membrane, such as by lipid peroxidation (Figure 5).81 On the other hand, the potential production of H2O2 and formation of other ROS could also be the cause of the antibacterial functions on the materials. This is because the benzophenone ketyl (BPK) radicals, produced in the BP incorporated polymer systems by abstracting hydrogen atoms from an H-donor, such as weak N–H and C–H bonds from polymers under photo-irradiation, would be rapidly re-oxidized in an atmosphere condition to form BP with an accompanying formation of H2O2, as shown in Figure 6.82,83 This reaction was confirmed by detecting H2O2 in water drops on the surface of BP incorporated polymer films with a peroxide test strip after UVA irradiation.69 Figure 3.
Enhanced permeability and retention spectra of pristine polystyrene scanned immediately after ultraviolet A (UVA) irradiation (a) and photo-irradiated poly(styrene- co-vinylbenzophenone) scanned at 1 min (b), at 5 min (c) and at 30 min (d) in an atmospheric dark chamber after UVA irradiation; temperature, 25 ± 5°C; microwave frequency, 9.663 GHz; power, 16 dB; modulation frequency, 50 KHz; modulation amplitude, 20 GHz.
Figure 4.
Schematic states of untreated poly(styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) (a), excited triplet biradicals of the poly(styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) (b) and hydroxyketyl radicals and macroradicals of the poly(styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) (c).
Figure 5.
Potential peroxidation reaction involving a fatty acid in cell membrane of bacteria. BP: benzophenone, UV: ultraviolet.
Figure 6.
Schematic reaction of producing hydrogen peroxide in the benzophenone (BP) structure.
Table 2.

The anthraquinone compounds, including 2-anthraquinone sulfonate (2-AQS), 2,6-anthraquinone sulfonate (2,6-AQS), 2,7-anthraquinone sulfonate (2,7-AQS) and 2-anthraquinone carboxylic acid (2-AQC), have revealed photo-induced antimicrobial functions on polyamide, wool and cotton fabrics. The mechanism of the photo-active functions was the same as BP and its derivatives: the formation of ROS through triplet excited status of the compounds.73,74

On the other hand, the polymeric radicals generated in this photo reaction could be employed in graft polymerization if another reactive monomer is provided in the system. In fact, such a reaction was utilized by the researchers as well. Studies on radical graft polymerization by photo-initiating the BP and anthraquinone compounds that are incorporated on surfaces of polymers and fibers proved the reaction, which is consistent with the proposed mechanism.71,73

sec.title: Photo-induced detoxification of organic photo-active agents
sec.p:
TiO2 can decontaminate toxic chemicals and decolorize dyes.45 Similarly, organic photo-sensitizers, such as BP structures, demonstrated the ability to decolorize some dyes.39,40 Poly (styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) was able to decolorize methylene blue and methyl orange.66–68 The absorbance at 600–700 nm significantly decreased in the spectrum of methylene blue solution containing the poly (styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone), possibly due to radicals resulted on the poly (styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) under the daylight. This result was confirmed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) chromatograms of the methylene blue solution and methyl orange, as shown in Figures 7 and 8. The peaks at 12.33 and 12.73 min in the spectrum of fresh methylene blue solution completely disappeared in the spectrum of methylene blue solution containing the poly (styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone). Therefore, it was verified that the photo-activated BP incorporated polymer materials could decompose chemicals such as methylene blue and methyl orange under UVA or fluorescent light.66,68 Although these photo-active polymers were slower in decolorizing these dyes than TiO2, they did show potential to be employed as decontaminating materials. In particular, azo dyes account for 60–70% of all dyes and pigments used, which is a concern due to the toxicity, mutagenicity and carcinogenicity of the dyes and their biotransformation products.76 Therefore, the ability of reducing azo dyes by the photo-activated poly (styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) seems inspirational for applications of the polymer in color removal in wastewater produced from textile dyeing. In addition, we also observed that the excited BP radicals could decompose some carbamate pesticides, such as Aldicarb, effectively, as shown in Figure 9.67 Figure 7.
High-performance liquid chromatograms of methylene blue/isopropyl alcohol solutions; initial (a), polystyrene immersed and left indoor for 6 months (b) and poly(styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) immersed and left indoor for 6 months (c).
Figure 8.
High-performance liquid chromatograms of methyl orange/water solutions; initial (a), poly(styrene-co-vinylbenzophenone) immersed and irradiated under ultraviolet A light for 27 h (b).
Figure 9.
High-performance liquid chromatograms of aldicarb aqueous solutions after ultraviolet A irradiation: (a) pristine cotton fabric immersed and (b) benzophenone incorporated cotton fabric immersed.
Anthraquinone derivative-treated textiles again showed a similar photo-induced decoloration and detoxification functions on textiles.74,84–88

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Polymeric materials incorporated with photo-active groups could provide environmentally friendly photo-induced antibacterial ability, as well as decontamination functions, which can be used in biological and chemical protective clothing products. In addition, the antimicrobial finishing of cotton fabric showed reasonable durability against washing and ageing in an atmospheric condition. Research on the application of organic photo-active agents is relatively new; however, organic photo-active agents have a bright future in textiles and polymers. Therefore, continued research on employing these agents on polymers could result in useful and environmentally friendly decontamination of materials.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
